Biology_181_p.News Finding: The key to printing tiny, precise, high-resolution patterns is in the amount of pressure applied to stamp the ink.
Biology_181_p.Paper Finding: When this stamp is used to print, the excess ink spreads upon contact, resulting in greater width and corner roundness of the printed features compared to the stamp and an overall loss of pattern fidelity ( fig.
Biology_181_p.News Context: "The forests of carbon nanotubes can transfer ink onto a surface like massive numbers of tiny pen quills." The key to printing tiny, precise, high-resolution patterns is in the amount of pressure applied to stamp the ink. "We found, limited by the motor we used in the printing system, we could print at 200 millimeters per second, continuously, which is already competitive with the rates of industrial printing technologies.
Biology_181_p.Paper Context: However, we find that a slight amount of excess ink is present on the stamp surface. When this stamp is used to print, the excess ink spreads upon contact, resulting in greater width and corner roundness of the printed features compared to the stamp and an overall loss of pattern fidelity ( fig. When the CNT stamp is then used for printing, uniform ink transfer is achieved by relying on the formation of nanoscale contact points across the surface of each microscale stamp feature, therefore replicating the shapes of the stamp features with high accuracy.
Biology_181_p.text: ['Finding: When this stamp is used to print, the excess ink spreads upon contact, resulting in greater width and corner roundness of the printed features compared to the stamp and an overall loss of pattern fidelity ( fig.']
Biology_181_p.displayed_text: Finding: When this stamp is used to print, the excess ink spreads upon contact, resulting in greater width and corner roundness of the printed features compared to the stamp and an overall loss of pattern fidelity ( fig.

Biology_248_r.News Finding: "We saw drastic changes in the babies' immune system between each sampling, which shows that it is highly dynamic early in life."
Biology_248_r.Paper Finding: Collectively, these findings highlight the reactive nature of the human immune system with implications, not only for our under-standing of newborn immune systems, but also for our understanding of human immune system variation in general and how this is shaped by environmental influences.
Biology_248_r.News Context: "We saw drastic changes in the babies' immune system between each sampling, which shows that it is highly dynamic early in life." Only small amounts of blood, just a few drops from each baby, are needed to analyse all the white blood cells and hundreds of proteins circulating in the blood. The researchers were also able to show that the babies who had abnormal development of the gut flora during the first weeks also demonstrated a disorder of the immune system.
Biology_248_r.Paper Context: This model does not require inputs to be identical, as long as the number of simultaneous inputs is sufficiently large and give rise to different adaptive responses. Collectively, these findings highlight the reactive nature of the human immune system with implications, not only for our under-standing of newborn immune systems, but also for our understanding of human immune system variation in general and how this is shaped by environmental influences. We also propose that in-depth analyses during early life adaptation to environmental influences provides a unique opportunity for better understanding the molecular mechanisms of immune system adaptation to environmental influences in humans.
Biology_248_r.text: ['Finding: "We saw drastic changes in the babies\' immune system between each sampling, which shows that it is highly dynamic early in life."']
Biology_248_r.displayed_text: Finding: "We saw drastic changes in the babies' immune system between each sampling, which shows that it is highly dynamic early in life."

Biology_220_r.News Finding: By further aggregating CNVs and SNVs (the latter identified in other studies), Mount Sinai researchers discovered many additional genes and pathways involved in ASD.
Biology_220_r.Paper Finding: Examples of ASD candidate genes identified by small de novo CNVs include SETD5, DTNA (MIM 6012), and LSAMP (MIM 6032) (Supplemental Data section ''Highlighted Genes,'' Figures S9, S10, and S14).
Biology_220_r.News Context: Individuals with ASD carried more of these CNVs than individuals in the control group, and some of them were inherited while others were only present in offspring with ASD. By further aggregating CNVs and SNVs (the latter identified in other studies), Mount Sinai researchers discovered many additional genes and pathways involved in ASD. "We hope that these new findings will help group individuals with ASD based upon their genetic causes and lead to earlier diagnosis, and smarter, more focused therapies and interventions for autism spectrum disorders," said first author Dalila Pinto, PhD, Assistant Professor of Psychiatry, and Genetics and Genomic Sciences at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai.
Biology_220_r.Paper Context: We replicated previous observations, such as a de novo deletion intersecting PTCHD1AS in a male (adding to the evidence that both PTCHD1 and PTCHD1AS contribute to ASD risk 14 ) and de novo events involving the miRNA miR137 (MIM 614304) in 1p.2-p.3 in two subjects. Examples of ASD candidate genes identified by small de novo CNVs include SETD5, DTNA (MIM 6012), and LSAMP (MIM 6032) (Supplemental Data section ''Highlighted Genes,'' Figures S9, S10, and S14). Among the affected subjects with pathogenic CNVs, 63% (38/60) carried de novo events ( Figure 1C ), including two subjects with two pathogenic events each.
Biology_220_r.text: ['Finding: By further aggregating CNVs and SNVs (the latter identified in other studies), Mount Sinai researchers discovered many additional genes and pathways involved in ASD.']
Biology_220_r.displayed_text: Finding: By further aggregating CNVs and SNVs (the latter identified in other studies), Mount Sinai researchers discovered many additional genes and pathways involved in ASD.

Biology_35_r.News Finding:
CONCLUSIONS:

Our findings raise the prospect that the tissues harvested from equine ligaments up to 72 hours of post-mortem represent an available reservoir of specific stem cells.
Biology_35_r.Paper Finding: This study demonstrated that a viable stem cell population can be isolated and expanded from equine cadaver ligaments up to 72 hours post-mortem.
Biology_35_r.News Context:
Furthermore, TEM analysis confirmed the stemness of EC-MSCs and identified some cells with a typical neuronal morphology. CONCLUSIONS:

Our findings raise the prospect that the tissues harvested from equine ligaments up to 72 hours of post-mortem represent an available reservoir of specific stem cells. EC-MSCs could be a promising alternative source for tissue engineering and stem cell therapy in equine medicine.
Biology_35_r.Paper Context: These observations are also in accordance with another study on ultrastructural changes of MSCs during neuronal induction . This study demonstrated that a viable stem cell population can be isolated and expanded from equine cadaver ligaments up to 72 hours post-mortem. Differentiation assays, flow cytometry, immunofluorescence and TEM analyses confirmed the stemness of these cells.
Biology_35_r.text: ['Finding: CONCLUSIONS: Our findings raise the prospect that the tissues harvested from equine ligaments up to 72 hours of post-mortem represent an available reservoir of specific stem cells.']
Biology_35_r.displayed_text: Finding: CONCLUSIONS: Our findings raise the prospect that the tissues harvested from equine ligaments up to 72 hours of post-mortem represent an available reservoir of specific stem cells.

Biology_222_r.News Finding: Co-author Dr Palmer said: "Our research has shown that non-native plants are less widespread than native species, and are not increasing any more than native plants.
Biology_222_r.Paper Finding: In addition, native plants may have the capacity to out-compete or coexist with the invaders, at least in some local environments .
Biology_222_r.News Context: Co-author Dr Palmer said: "Our research has shown that non-native plants are less widespread than native species, and are not increasing any more than native plants. It therefore seems likely that factors other than plant invasions are the main causes of vegetation change." The study found that locations with high diversity of non-native species also support high diversity of native species, suggesting that high diversities of native and non-native plant species are compatible with one another.
Biology_222_r.Paper Context: Competition may be insufficient as a mechanism to drive many or any native plant species extinct, other than at a local scale . In addition, native plants may have the capacity to out-compete or coexist with the invaders, at least in some local environments . However, it is possible to evaluate two conditions that need to be met if past introductions are likely to cause future extinctions.
Biology_222_r.text: ['Finding: Co-author Dr Palmer said: "Our research has shown that non-native plants are less widespread than native species, and are not increasing any more than native plants.']
Biology_222_r.displayed_text: Finding: Co-author Dr Palmer said: "Our research has shown that non-native plants are less widespread than native species, and are not increasing any more than native plants.

Biology_tweet_15_r.News Finding: In our latest article, just out in @username  we found that <0.1% of fungi, mostly belonging to Ascomycota, dominate soils globally. We mapped their global distribution and found that contain multiple genes related to stress-tolerance & resource uptake
Biology_tweet_15_r.Paper Finding: Whole-genome comparisons with less dominant, generalist fungi point at a significantly higher number of genes related to stress-tolerance and resource uptake in the dominant fungi, suggesting that they might be better in colonising a wide range of environments.
Biology_tweet_15_r.News Context: In our latest article, just out in @username  we found that <0.1% of fungi, mostly belonging to Ascomycota, dominate soils globally. We mapped their global distribution and found that contain multiple genes related to stress-tolerance & resource uptake
Biology_tweet_15_r.Paper Context: Our findings indicate that 83 phylotypes (<0.1% of the retrieved fungi), mostly belonging to wind dispersed, generalist Ascomycota, dominate soils globally. Whole-genome comparisons with less dominant, generalist fungi point at a significantly higher number of genes related to stress-tolerance and resource uptake in the dominant fungi, suggesting that they might be better in colonising a wide range of environments. Our findings constitute a major advance in our understanding of the ecology of fungi, and have implications for the development of strategies to preserve them and the ecosystem functions they provide.

Biology_417_r.News Finding: The researchers determined that, while climate change likely has been and will be a factor in the decline of some local populations such as in the Rocky Mountain West -- where the effect of a warming climate seems to be more severe for amphibians -- it is not responsible for the current declines that are occurring.
Biology_417_r.Paper Finding: While we demonstrate that amphibian communities are sensitive to changes in climate, our results suggest that changing climate is not the proximate cause for ongoing assemblage-wide declines that have been observed in North American amphibians.
Biology_417_r.News Context: For example, they found that less precipitation during breeding seasons generally has a negative effect on amphibian populations, while less snowfall during winter may benefit many populations. The researchers determined that, while climate change likely has been and will be a factor in the decline of some local populations such as in the Rocky Mountain West -- where the effect of a warming climate seems to be more severe for amphibians -- it is not responsible for the current declines that are occurring. "It depends on the location whether habitat loss, disease, contaminants, climate, or a combination of these local factors is the culprit," she said.
Biology_417_r.Paper Context: For example, we found that summer drought has the strongest impact in warm and dry regions, decreased snowfall has a smaller effect in eastern compared to western North America, and winter warming is predicted to decrease species richness for all species groups except tree frogs. While we demonstrate that amphibian communities are sensitive to changes in climate, our results suggest that changing climate is not the proximate cause for ongoing assemblage-wide declines that have been observed in North American amphibians. Instead, we find that recent change in climate is a strong predictor of why local species richness is declining more quickly in some regions and that positive effects of climate may be buffering declines in other regions.
Biology_417_r.text: ['Finding: The researchers determined that, while climate change likely has been and will be a factor in the decline of some local populations such as in the Rocky Mountain West -- where the effect of a warming climate seems to be more severe for amphibians -- it is not responsible for the current declines that are occurring.']
Biology_417_r.displayed_text: Finding: The researchers determined that, while climate change likely has been and will be a factor in the decline of some local populations such as in the Rocky Mountain West -- where the effect of a warming climate seems to be more severe for amphibians -- it is not responsible for the current declines that are occurring.
